G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: This Complaint is brought pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 and G.L. c. 209C, § 20, requesting that the Court modify its prior custody order dated March 12, 2019, which established a 50/50 physical custody arrangement between the parties for their minor child, Sophia Smith.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: This Complaint is brought pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 and G.L. c. 209C, § 20, requesting that the Court modify its prior custody order dated March 12, 2019, which established a 50/50 physical custody arrangement between the parties for their minor child, Sophia Smith.

G.L. c. 208.proposition: The Probate and Family Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 208 and G.L. c. 209C, as the original custody order was issued in this Court, and the parties and minor child continue to reside in Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 209C.proposition: The Probate and Family Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 208 and G.L. c. 209C, as the original custody order was issued in this Court, and the parties and minor child continue to reside in Massachusetts.

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: Plaintiff’s proposed modification is centered on the minor child’s best interests, in compliance with G.L. c. 208, § 28 and G.L. c. 209C, § 20, which require “real advantage” to the child in any proposed modification (Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985)).
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: Yannas does articulate the ‘real advantage’ standard in removal cases and ties it to the child’s best interests, but it does not construe G.L. c. 208, § 28 or G.L. c. 209C, § 20, nor does it say those statutes “require ‘real advantage’ to the child in any proposed modification.” The opinion interprets the removal statute, G.L. c. 208, § 30, and explains that ‘real advantage’ refers initially to the custodial parent’s good reason to move, with the child’s best interests then evaluated holistically. Thus, citing Yannas for a statutory requirement in §§ 28 and 20 is inaccurate and overstates its holding.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that… ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child… An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change (including any improvement flowing from an improvement in the quality of the custodial parent’s life)… In this process, the first consideration is whether there is a good reason for the move, a ‘real advantage.’”

Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.raw_text: Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734, 738 (1996)
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.proposition: A parenting arrangement established by court order may be modified upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and when such modification is in the child's best interests (G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734, 738 (1996)).
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion directly interprets G.L. c. 208, § 28, stating that a Probate Court judge may modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning custody upon finding a “material and substantial change in the circumstances” and that the modification “is necessary in the best interests of the children.” The court applies this standard to the mother’s complaint for modification. Although it does not cite G.L. c. 209C, § 20, the articulated rule for modification of a custody arrangement clearly matches the proposition for court-ordered parenting arrangements under § 28.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28, as amended through St. 1993, c. 460, enables a Probate Court judge, upon finding that ‘a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred’ to modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody arrangements of minor children, where the modification ‘is necessary in the best interests of the children.’”

Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488, 494 (2012.proposition: The Massachusetts courts have consistently held that a child's safety, welfare, and happiness are paramount considerations in custody determinations (Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488, 494 (2012); Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182, 187 (1998)).
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488, 494 (2012.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly discusses the Massachusetts custody standard, stating that the “touchstone inquiry” is what is best for the child and citing Rosenberg v. Merida for the requirement to weigh all relevant factors affecting the child’s welfare. While it does not use the exact phrase “safety, welfare, and happiness,” its articulation of the best-interests standard and its focus on the child’s needs, harm, stability, and relationships align with the proposition that the child’s welfare is paramount in custody determinations.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488, 494 (2012.relevant_excerpt: “Parents have an equal right to custody of their children. … ‘In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is] … what is “best for the child” ….’ Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840 (2003). ‘The determination of which parent will promote a child’s best interests rests within the discretion of the judge … [whose] findings … “must stand unless they are plainly wrong.”’ Id. at 845, quoting Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182, 191 (1998). However, the judge must weigh ‘all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child.’”}

Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182, 187.proposition: The Massachusetts courts have consistently held that a child's safety, welfare, and happiness are paramount considerations in custody determinations (Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488, 494 (2012); Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182, 187 (1998)).
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182, 187.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns SSDI credits toward child support, attachment to secure support/college expenses, and modification of legal custody. In the custody section, it refers to the statutory standard that modification must be in the 'best interests of the child,' but it does not articulate or emphasize a broader principle that the child's safety, welfare, and happiness are 'paramount considerations' in custody determinations. The language is more about the need to weigh all relevant factors and make specific findings, so it does not clearly establish the specific proposition cited.
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182, 187.relevant_excerpt: General Laws c. 208, § 28, provides that a Probate and Family Court judge may modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody of a minor child on finding “that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the child[].” ... However, we shall not sustain an award of custody “unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed.”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 182-83.proposition: Imposing age-inappropriate caregiving responsibilities on the child constitutes a disruption of her best interests and justifies modification of the custody order (Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 182-83 (2006)).
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 182-83.support_reasoning: The opinion is a removal/relocation case focused on the best‑interests analysis when parents share joint physical custody. The court discusses school quality, disruption from relocation, the child’s special needs, parental conflict, and allegations of misconduct by a step‑sibling, but it does not address or identify “age‑inappropriate caregiving responsibilities” imposed on the child as a factor, nor does it state that such caregiving justifies modification of custody. The proposition therefore misstates and overextends what Mason v. Coleman actually holds.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 182-83.relevant_excerpt: “The order is based on the judge’s findings that the children’s best interests would be negatively affected by this move. She made detailed written findings that their current schools were superior, that uprooting the children would be difficult for them, that the move would impair the father’s parenting to the detriment of their interests, that potential misconduct by other siblings in the mother’s household weighed against increased physical custody by the mother, and that any financial or other advantage of the move to the mother was unclear.”

Chapin v. Chapin, 447 Mass. 565, 572 (20.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that a stable and safe environment is critical to a child’s development, and modifications may be warranted to ensure this stability (Chapin v. Chapin, 447 Mass. 565, 572 (2006)).
Chapin v. Chapin, 447 Mass. 565, 572 (20.support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal homicide/arson appeal and does not concern Massachusetts domestic relations law, child custody, or modification standards. There is no discussion of a child’s developmental needs, stable or safe environments, or modification of any custody or parenting orders. Accordingly, it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition about Massachusetts law recognizing the importance of a stable and safe environment for a child and permitting modifications to ensure that stability.

Woodside v. Woodside, 79 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Woodside v. Woodside, 79 Mass. App. Ct. 713, 718 (2011)
Woodside v. Woodside, 79 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Where one parent can no longer effectively safeguard the child’s physical and emotional well-being, the Court has discretion to reassign custodial responsibilities to the other parent to serve the child’s best interests (Woodside v. Woodside, 79 Mass. App. Ct. 713, 718 (2011)).
Woodside v. Woodside, 79 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The case is a removal and alimony decision; it does not involve a change in legal or physical custody from one parent to the other based on a finding that a parent can no longer safeguard a child’s well-being. The opinion applies the Yannas/Mason removal framework and focuses on best interests in the context of relocation, not reassignment of custodial responsibilities. There is no discussion of reallocating custody because one parent failed to protect the child, so the proposition mischaracterizes the holding of Woodside.
Woodside v. Woodside, 79 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “Removal petitions are evaluated under one of two analyses. When a parent with sole physical custody of the child seeks to relocate the child outside the Commonwealth over the objection of the noncustodial parent, the real advantage test…applies… If the parent seeking removal…shares physical custody… the advantage to the moving parent becomes merely a relevant factor in the over-all inquiry of what is in the child’s best interests.” (79 Mass. App. Ct. at 716-717).
